title: 113_s1073
content: The Gas Price and Refinery Capacity Relief Act of 2013, also known as the "Gas Price and Refinery Capacity Relief Act," amends Section 804 of the Energy Independence and Security Act of 2007 to coordinate refinery outages. The Gas Price and Refinery Capacity Relief Act of 2013 defines key terms related to refinery outages, such as Administrator, planned refinery outage, refined petroleum product, refinery, and unplanned refinery outage. The Gas Price and Refinery Capacity Relief Act of 2013 requires refinery owners to report planned and unplanned refinery outages to the Administrator in advance. The Administrator reviews and analyzes this information to assess the impact on refined petroleum product inventories and production. The Gas Price and Refinery Capacity Relief Act of 2013 mandates refinery owners to report refinery outages to the Administrator for analysis. The Administrator assesses if the outage may affect the price or supply of refined petroleum products nationally or regionally. If so, the Secretary provides information to prevent market disruptions. The Gas Price and Refinery Capacity Relief Act of 2013 requires refinery operators to report outages for analysis. The Secretary is not authorized to alter legal obligations, create rights of action, or interfere with refinery operations. A study on a national strategic refined petroleum products reserve is to be conducted within 180 days, assessing costs and benefits. The Gas Price and Refinery Capacity Relief Act of 2013 mandates a study on increasing storage capacity for refined petroleum products regionally to assess the impact on consumer prices during supply shortages or market disruptions.
